pages.text: Maiaspondylus comes from the Cretaceous, with fossils found in the Loon River and Clearwater Formations, Canada; Cambridge Greensands, England (United Kingdom), and Western European Russia. It is a large platypterygine, growing up to roughly 3.5 m in length. Originally referred to Platypterygius, recent cladistic studies on it found it to be its own valid genus, although it is still apart of the platypterygiine subfamily.

One fossil specimen of Maiaspondylus is known for bearing the (Geologically) youngest and smallest known ichthyosaur embryos. The generic name derives from the Greek words 'Maia', to mean 'good mother'; and 'spondylus', to mean 'vertebrae'.
